When, who, how, and why was Al-Aqsa built?

> Both structures {the “Dome of the Rock” shrine and the “al-Aqsa” mosque) were built on the Herodian “Temple Mount” referred to by Arabs as the Haram al-Sharif. Judean King Herod built the Temple Mount in the year 19 BCE, building massive retaining walls around the original mountain and backfilling it to create a flat plaza of approximately 150,000 square meters. The rebuilt Herodian Jewish Temple that stood on the expanded Temple Mount was destroyed by the forces of Roman General Titus about 90 years later, in the year 70CE. Reliefs of the sacking of the temple are depicted on the Arch of Titus in Rome, which was erected ten years after the Temple’s destruction.

The “Dome of the Rock” was built in 691 and the “al-Aqsa” mosque in 705. Jews visiting the Temple Mount are not permitted to enter these structures. They are restricted by the Waqf to paths around the perimeter of the plaza. As far a prayers are concerned, no one is arguing for Jews to be permitted to openly perform services on the Temple Mount, although it is ludicrous that the idea is so shocking, considering the fact that the Moslems appropriated the site of the Jewish Temple six hundred years after the Romans destroyed it, clearly identifying the site as an originally Jewish site that was re-purposed by the Moslems specifically because of its existing sanctity.

What Jews find repugnant and obnoxious is the idea that a brief blessing whispered by a Jewish person in silence to his or herself is treated as an offense against “Allah” and the entire Arab world.

It took a quarter of a century for a US president to build up the audacity to carry out the Jerusalem Embassy Act, passed by congress in 1995. The excuse of each president before Trump for failing to carry out the will of Congress was the risk that carrying out the law could lead to Arab “unrest”. The same excuse is used by the Israel police when they enforce the policy of banning Jews from saying even a brief, silent prayer to themselves while visiting the Temple Mount. Israel’s supreme court declared that “every Jew has the right to pray on the Temple Mount, as part of their guaranteed freedom of religion and expression.” The Supreme court also added that “At the same time, these rights are not absolute, and can be limited to take into account the public interest.” The police take that to mean that, while in principle Jews should be permitted to pray, in practice they will never permit it because it is against the “public interest” to risk causing the Arabs to riot, as if the Arabs don’t riot regardless.

In 1990, people could just walk right up there, and take a tour. It was open to anybody. No metal detectors, no heavy military or police presence -

After the Intifada, things tightened down - a bit gradually, but by 2006 at least, access to the platform was very limited, and there were metal detectors for people entering the plaza in front of the Western Wall from the parking area near the City of David excavations.

But in 1990, anybody could just walk right up - which my husband and I did, due to getting completely lost and turned around, and walking in from the east (I think).

Today, Jews are not allowed to pray there, but I am not absolutely certain about ‘not allowed to go’ at all. I THINK there is some limited access, if it is pre-arranged.

As for the Dome of the Rock - that is a world treasure as far as I’m concerned. I would no more want to see it destroyed than I would want to see the Pyramids converted to casinos or something.

It is the normal position among Jews, for a very long time, that the Temple will be rebuilt BY the messiah, AFTER achieving World Peace, and my main hope for that is that the Dome of the Rock might be, perhaps, very gently moved over a bit…or something.

As explained here: “Visiting the Temple Mount and Dome of the Rock”

… visitors may not bring in any sacred Jewish objects, such as a prayer book or a tallit. Visitors may be asked to show their passports.

While the complex is open to all people, non-Muslim visitors will NOT be allowed entry into the building of the Dome of the Rock.

The atmosphere around the Dome of the Rock is quite honestly tense and unpleasant for visitors; the rules imposed by the Jerusalem waqf for visitors seem much stricter than for other major mosques visited by tourists. The guardians of the mosque seem almost paranoid about Jewish visitors trying to pray on the Temple Mount — which is a politically explosive issue in Jerusalem:

5 Israeli restriction policy

Jewish prayer on Temple Mount is completely forbidden. Jews may enter only to visit the place, and only at limited times. Muslims are free to pray on Temple Mount, however, Christians and Jews may only visit the site as tourists. They are forbidden from singing, praying, or making any kind of "religious displays".

By contrast, I’ve been to the Blue Mosque in Istanbul and the atmosphere was very relaxed and welcoming, with tourists of all kinds of backgrounds. Visitors could go in and take photos, but were asked to be quiet and respectful and not to enter the prayer area unless praying. Women received shawls to cover their hair and shoulders, and men to cover bare legs… so there were quite a few men walking around in makeshift skirts :-D.

When did Israel gain control of Jerusalem?

The British abandoned control of Jerusalem, along with the rest of the country, in 1948. When a ceasefire was signed between Israel and the Jordanian invaders in 1949, Israel wound up in control of what today is called West Jerusalem (although that’s a geographic oversimplification) and an isolated bit of East Jerusalem; Jordan had the rest, except a strip of no-man’s land that skirted the Old City. Defending itself against Jordanian attack in 1967, Israel gained control of East Jerusalem along with the West Bank. Israel then annexed Jerusalem in a united and expanded form that included severa

The British abandoned control of Jerusalem, along with the rest of the country, in 1948. When a ceasefire was signed between Israel and the Jordanian invaders in 1949, Israel wound up in control of what today is called West Jerusalem (although that’s a geographic oversimplification) and an isolated bit of East Jerusalem; Jordan had the rest, except a strip of no-man’s land that skirted the Old City. Defending itself against Jordanian attack in 1967, Israel gained control of East Jerusalem along with the West Bank. Israel then annexed Jerusalem in a united and expanded form that included several outlying villages.

Some people from other religions when attacking Judaism like to claim that we don’t follow the Torah because we don’t offer sacrifices anymore. They claim that the Rabbi’s just wanted to grab power for themselves and thus removed sacrifices, made up the excuse that sacrifices have to be offered in the Temple, and then stopped the rebuilding of the Temple. One of the things they try to bring to show they are right is the fact that Moses offered sacrifices in the desert. So, let us look at what the Torah and Tanakh have to say on this topic.

18. And he shall then place some of the blood on the horns of the altar that is before the Lord in the Tent of Meeting. And then he shall pour all the blood onto the base of the altar [used] for burnt offerings, which is at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting. יח. וּמִן הַדָּם יִתֵּן עַל קַרְנֹת הַמִּזְבֵּחַ אֲשֶׁר לִפְנֵי יְ־הֹוָ־ה אֲשֶׁר בְּאֹהֶל מוֹעֵד וְאֵת כָּל הַדָּם יִשְׁפֹּךְ אֶל יְסוֹד מִזְבַּח הָעֹלָה אֲשֶׁר פֶּתַח אֹהֶל מוֹעֵד:

I could go on like this through the book of Vayikra, and show others from Devarim, but the point has been made. Sacrifices in the desert (and before the building of the Temple) had to be made at the tent of meeting by the Kohanim (Aharon and his descendants)- i.e. the Mishkan. Before that they could be made anywhere. Since Moshe only offered sacrifices before the investure of Aharon and his sons, these laws never applied until they became relevant.

Hmm, but why do we say this is the only place they could be offered? Perhaps they could be offered elsewhere as well and this was just the best case scenario and preferred method rather than the only method? To teach us otherwise the Torah states:

Vayikra Chapter 17

What happened to the third temple of Jerusalem?

Julian the Apostate, a former Christian turned pagan, planned to rebuild the Jerusalem temple during the fourth century, to provide a degree of equality for Christians, pagans and Jews—this would have been the third temple. Unfortunately for the Jews, he was killed in battle and his Christian successors promptly cancelled the rebuilding plans.

Why did Jews leave Israel?

One of the great historical misconceptions is the notion that the Romans expelled the Jews from what was then Judea and is now Israel. The Romans never actually forced the Jews to leave en masse, but after the revolt of First Jewish Revolt of 70 CE, when the Temple was destroyed and even more so after the Bar Kochba revolt, which began in 132, the Romans did make Jewish life in the region almost impossible. By the time the second revolt was over, the area was ruined and depopulated. A Roman city had been constructed on the ruins of Jerusalem and Jews had been banned from the city and Jewish religious practices had been forbidden. Hadrian had even renamed the territory “Syria Palestina”, just to make sure no one thought of it as Jewish again. The period is commemorated to this day in Judaism, most notably in the Martyrology section of the Yom Kippur service, which recounts the death of various sages at Roman hands. The destruction was so thorough that Judea/Palestine never really recovered-it remained largely depopulated and undeveloped until the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948. Given that situation, it’s not surprising that many of the remaining Jews immigrated someplace else, just as Syrian refugees do today. However, some Jews did remain and, over the centuries, others returned, eventually reestablishing thriving communities in places like Jerusalem and Safed.

Was Jerusalem built by Jews?

Before the Israelites under King David captured Jerusalem (II Sam. V 6–9) — which lay midway between David’s initial kingdom of Judah in the South (II Sam. II 1-4) and the Kingdom ruled by Saul’s son, Ish-Baal, in the North (II Sam. II 8–11) —, Jerusalem had been held by the Jebusites (II Sam. V 6).

The point of taking Jerusalem and making it his capital was apparently to have a capital which both was centrally located (unlike, say, his old capital of Hebron) and lay on neutral ground (i.e. it had belonged neither to David’s southern Kingdom nor to Ish-Baal’s northern Kingdom).

Before the Israelites under King David captured Jerusalem (II Sam. V 6–9) — which lay midway between David’s initial kingdom of Judah in the South (II Sam. II 1-4) and the Kingdom ruled by Saul’s son, Ish-Baal, in the North (II Sam. II 8–11) —, Jerusalem had been held by the Jebusites (II Sam. V 6).

The point of taking Jerusalem and making it his capital was apparently to have a capital which both was centrally located (unlike, say, his old capital of Hebron) and lay on neutral ground (i.e. it had belonged neither to David’s southern Kingdom nor to Ish-Baal’s northern Kingdom).

But, to stick strictly to the question, the Israelites did not build Jerusalem. Before them the Jebusites had held the city, but whether these Jebusites had originally built it is on current evidence an unanswerable question. There are mentions of Jerusalem in the Amarna Letters from the 14th century B.C., but from memory no specific name is applied to the city’s inhabitants in those texts. So it is unclear whether the Jebusites already held the city in the 14th century B.C. They might have entered/conquered the city later.

What are the most interesting points of the Dome of the Rock?

The spot upon which the Dome of the Rock stands has a greater history than the building itself.

It begins close to 3000 years ago with the construction of the first Jewish Temple. The Temple stood for over 400 years before falling at the hands of the Babylonians. The second Jewish Temple also stood more than 400 years before the Roman’s laid siege on Jerusalem and turned it to rubble.

While the Roman’s held control over the site, they supposedly built a pagan Temple. However, some scholars believe this temple was located elsewhere in the city. Over the centuries, the pagan shrines on the Temple

The spot upon which the Dome of the Rock stands has a greater history than the building itself.

It begins close to 3000 years ago with the construction of the first Jewish Temple. The Temple stood for over 400 years before falling at the hands of the Babylonians. The second Jewish Temple also stood more than 400 years before the Roman’s laid siege on Jerusalem and turned it to rubble.

While the Roman’s held control over the site, they supposedly built a pagan Temple. However, some scholars believe this temple was located elsewhere in the city. Over the centuries, the pagan shrines on the Temple Mount crumbled.

Later, Jerusalem came under the control of Muslim armies. They didn’t build the Dome of the Rock instantly but a few leaders later. Eventually, Caliph Abd al-Malik built the Dome of the Rock. But that’s not the end of the story.

In 1099, a pilgrimage of armed Christians wrestled away the Holy Land from the Muslims during a series of holy wars known as the Crusades. A cross was placed atop the Dome of the Rock and converted into a church known as Templum Domini.

But Jerusalem changed hands again in 1187, when an Ottoman army headed by Saladin captured it from the Christians. Saladin destroyed the Christian buildings, removing the cross atop the Dome of the Rock and replacing it with a crescent.

It has remained the same since. Currently, non-Muslims are banned from entering.

Why did Ashkenazi Jews leave Israel if there were always Jews living in Israel?

When the Jews were expelled from Israel there were no Ashkenazi, Sephardi or Mizrachi Jews. There were Jews - some of whom lived in Egypt (Alexandrian Jews), some who lived in Babylon (Babylonian Jews), and Judean Jews (who were expelled en-masse from most of Judea but not from areas like the Galilee where they continued living).

There was also, at that time, no “Israel” as a country we know to day. There was the Roman Province of Judea. (Named JUDEA because it was where Jews lived as their ancestral homeland). When the Jews of Judea were expelled, the Romans renamed the province as Palestine (and also renamed Jerusalem as Aelia Capotilina) - the aim being that the land had been emptied of Jews. This is where the name Palestine comes from: the ETHNIC CLEANSING of the indigenous inhabitants who managed to return to their homeland c1900 years later.

On expulsion, Jews fled or were taken as slaves to other parts of the Roman empire - primarily Europe. The descendants of these Jews (and other Jews who moved to Northern Europe) became known as Ashkenazi Jews - but this was almost 1000 years later. Those who moved to Spain became known as Sephardi Jews and most Babylonian Jews became known as Mizrachi Jews. These names only started to be used around 900 years ago. There are also other smaller lesser known communities e.g. Romaniote Jews from Greece.

The names describe religious customs that differed in the various communities. For example Ashkenazi Jews have different rules on what they can eat on Passover from Sephardi and Mizrachi Jews. (They traditionally don’t eat rice and legumes whereas other Jews do). In contrast Sephardi Jews have stricter rules on checking meat for status as Kosher than Ashkenazi Jews. (Ashkenazi Jews allow certain nodules on an animals lungs that Sephardi/Mizrachi Jews forbid). These differences only arose hundreds of years after the expulsion from Judea and their origins are often due to the different lives people lived in, for example, a cold climate where the dominant religion was Christianity (Ashkenazi Jews) and a warm or hot climate where Islam dominated (Sephardi / Mizrachi Jews).

Ashkenaz was the Hebrew word for Northern Europe / Germany. Sepharad is the Hebrew word for Spain. Mizrach is the Hebrew word for East - hence Eastern Jews are Mizrachi; Jews who trace origins back to Spain are Sephardi and Jews who trace origins to Northern Europe are Ashkenazi.

I’m no expert in all of Judaism, but I’m going to say: Not as important as you think. Here’s why:

  1. Judaism isn’t very messianic. We just don’t focus on that as a religion. It’s something we hope for every so often. Something we build towards. Focusing on improving how we live (as people serving G-d) is more important.
  2. Our religion has changed a lot since the destruction of the Second Temple. Think about it: the Judaism described in the Tanakh is not rabbinical Judaism. We don’t make and burn sacrifices anymore, for example. Mainly because we don’t have a temple. So we changed our religion so that we could still try to show our devotion to G-d and maintain our culture without a temple.
  3. Israel is a mess and there’s kind of a mosque on our temple. If the building of the third temple is supposed to trigger the messianic age in Judaism (Specifically in Judaism for the sake of this answer), we’re really far away from achieving that. There’s supposed to be no war or hunger. Meanwhile Israel is… Well, I don’t think I need to tell you what it is or invite commentary on that situation. Suffice to say, everyone’s hoping it’s a problem that will find a solution sooner rather than later. But if we get rid of the Al-Aqsa Mosque on the Temple Mount, I do think that will just make everything worse, and therefore we can’t trigger the messianic age that way. Better to work on Israel as a whole first, focus on the Third Temple later once.

Besides, according to a bunch of old Jewish texts, we’ve still got about another 221 years before the Messiah has to show up.

Why was the Temple Mount built in the place of the Jerusalem Temple?

“Is there enough space on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem to build a Third Jewish Temple without destroying the currently existing structures on the Mount? If there is enough space would it even be a good idea to build it on the Temple Mount.”

In a perfect world, perhaps Muslims and Jews could figure out a way to share the Temple Mount plaza, with room for both the 1300-year-old Dome of the Rock and al-Aqsa Mosque, and also a rebuilt Third Temple.

As it is, in terms of already-high tensions between Muslims and Jews in that spot, even trying it would be, at best, a Very Bad Idea. Wars have started over less. (The Second Intifada, if memory serves, started when a prominent Israeli politician said that he wanted to visit the Temple Mount.)

I’m not aware of any prominent Jewish group that seriously wants to build the Third Temple. Judaism has evolved since the Second Temple has been destroyed, and the evolutions have stuck; Judaism has now existed without a Temple for longer than the Temple existed.

Judaism no longer needs a Temple, nor is eager to resume doing the things that were done when the Temple stood. Animal sacrifices? A hereditary priesthood?

Some customs have changed or been lost in the past 2,000 years. For example, once the Name of God was pronounced once a year, by the High Priest, on Yom Kippur; he would enter the Holy of Holies chamber, get down on his knees, and address God by name as he begged forgiveness for the entire Jewish people. When the Temple was destroyed, that information was lost; we genuinely no longer know how the Name of God was pronounced. (And that seems an important thing to get right, doesn’t it?)

In many ways, the subject is a little reminiscent of a child leaving home, and returning back there as an adult. Things are not as she remembers, everything seems a little smaller and a little shabbier, and besides, she’s now outgrown childish things. Visiting the childhood home can be extremely nostalgic, but she’s outgrown it; it’s no longer home.

Currently, Muslims pray up on the Temple Mount, and Jews pray down below at the Western Wall. That’s probably as reasonable a status quo as we could hope for.

When did the Jews build Jerusalem?

In the late bronze age, the city of Jerusalem, already inhabited by the Jebusites was conquered by the Jewish King David.

Over the next three millennium until today, various rulers and inhabitants have built and rebuilt the city. The actual city limits has expanded, contracted and morphed over time. Much of Today’s Jerusalem old city is built on layer upon later of former building remnants.

Building in Jerusalem continued on and off for the last 3,000 years. In those long periods when Jews were the prominent inhabitants, there was much building. Notably King Solomon taxed his Jewish nation very

In the late bronze age, the city of Jerusalem, already inhabited by the Jebusites was conquered by the Jewish King David.

Over the next three millennium until today, various rulers and inhabitants have built and rebuilt the city. The actual city limits has expanded, contracted and morphed over time. Much of Today’s Jerusalem old city is built on layer upon later of former building remnants.

Building in Jerusalem continued on and off for the last 3,000 years. In those long periods when Jews were the prominent inhabitants, there was much building. Notably King Solomon taxed his Jewish nation very heavily to pay for building works, particularly the First Jewish Temple in Jerusalem.

When Ezra and Nehemiah Returned to Zion from the Babylonian exile in the early 6th Century BCE, the small numbers of Jews that returned with them (perhaps 40,000) were very preoccupied in rebuilding the destroyed Jewish Temple and Jerusalem’s previously demolished fortified walls. This included setting guard watches to defend the workers and the building sites from constant raids of Non-Jewish groups intent of stopping such work.

In the middle of the 19th Century while still under Ottoman rule there was an impetus to escape the then crowded and unsanitary old city. Jews were amongst those that began to build what were then fortified suburbs outside of the “Old City Walls”. The first Jewish built new suburb was Mishkenot Sha'ananim. Today, those original new suburbs have been subsumed in the sizeable metropolis that is modern Jerusalem.

Jerusalem today.
